titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Joan Kahn Papers
titlestmt.author: by H. Dean

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 03:54

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Joan Kahn Papers document her work as a suspense book editor in New York City and largely consist of correspondence and dust jackets spanning from 1945 to 1989. Correspondence includes letters from: Jacques Barzun, Maurice Procter, and Julian Symons. Also included are other papers (such as notes for a business trip) dating from 1964 and 1975.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Joan Kahn Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Joan Kahn Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

bioghist.head: Joan Kahn (1914-1994)
bioghist.p: Joan Kahn was an editor of suspense novels and worked at firms including Harper and Row, Ticknor and Fields, Dutton, and St. Martin's Press during a career that spanned over forty years. Kahn also wrote two novels ( To Meet Miss Long and Open House ) and four children's books as well as edited eleven mystery anthologies.

Born in New York City, Kahn attended the Horace Mann School and pursued post-secondary education at the Yale School of Art, Barnard College and the Art Students' League. In 1946 Kahn began her career at Harper Brothers where she initially edited books about history, art, theater, and travel before starting the Harper Novels of Suspense Department. In the 1960s Kahn had her own imprint ("Joan Kahn Books") and the Mystery Writers of America awarded her the Ellery Queen Award and the Edgar Allan Poe Award in recognition of her distinguished career in publishing. Kahn died in New York City at the age of eighty in 1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Joan Kahn Papers document her work as a suspense book editor in New York City and largely consist of correspondence and dust jackets spanning from 1945 to 1989. Also included are Kahn's personal papers dating from 1964 and 1975.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Joan Kahn Papers are organized into the following three series: Correspondence, Other Papers, and Dust Jackets.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two subseries: incoming and outgoing correspondence. Both are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Kahn's professional correspondence. Among her correspondents are authors she published as well as fans (including Bess and Harry Truman and John F. Kennedy).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also contains a limited edition typescript copy of "The Newborn" by D.M.B. dated 1957 April 29 (inscribed to Kahn)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes one letter from Peter Escott

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes enclosed letter in Welsh to Menna Gallie from publisher Hughes A'I Fab. Also includes two letters from Gallie's husband Bryce Gallie

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains material relating to Kahn's work as an editor dating from roughly 1964 to 1975. Also included is the Program for Joan Kahn's memorial service in 1994.

did.unittitle: Publicity materials for Patrick McGinley's Bogmail
Program for Joan Kahn's memorial service

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by author and book title. Book jackets are filed under authors' published name, with pseudonyms cross-referenced where applicable.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains dust jackets from a number of books Kahn published dating largely from the late 1940s to the 1980s. The dust jackets are of particular interest because Kahn found her own jacket artists (including her sister Olivia Kahn) and wrote her own jacket copy.
